data.text: Content
Introduction

The  Trust  encourages  volunteers  within  the  hospital  and  acknowledges  the contribution made by volunteers. This policy defines volunteer recruitment, selection and screening procedure, the principles of effective volunteer management and the appropriate use of volunteers.

For the purpose of this policy, ‘volunteers' are defined as individuals who freely agree to provide a service to the hospital, through personal choice and without financial reward, except for out-of-pocket expenses.

Voluntary organisations and charities whose volunteers are on Trust premises are required to provide the Voluntary Services Department with full details of volunteers for inclusion on the database. They will also need to provide assurance that they have undertaken a recruitment process of their volunteers. Volunteers with these organisations and charities are required to undertake the same stat-man training as Trust volunteers. If required the Voluntary Services Department will support the external voluntary organisation with recruitment checks e.g. DBS clearances, so that assurance is met.
Scope

The Trust seeks to involve volunteers to complement the work of all Trust staff and thereby make a valued and valuable contribution to the patient experience, through their great diversity of skills, experience and enthusiasm.

The use of volunteers in the hospital is fully supported and actively encouraged by the Trust Board, senior management team and staff side. The Trust hopes to provide a positive volunteer role that will be of benefit not only to the volunteer but also to staff and patients.
Definitions

table_items.text: Volunteers activity by individuals undertaken freely that involves spending time, unpaid, doing something that aims to benefit the environment or individuals or groups other than (or in addition to) close relatives (DoH Strategic Vision for Volunteering, Oct 2011)

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Information Asset Owner
The Director Charities & Voluntary Services is the accountable Information Asset Owner (IAO) for the Trust Volunteer Register.
Information Asset Administrator

The Senior Voluntary Services Manager is the Information Asset Administrator (IAA) and is responsible for keeping the Trust Volunteer Register up to date and in line with the Trust's responsibilities under the Data Protection Act.
Voluntary Services Coordinator
The Voluntary Services coordinator is responsible for:
Ultimately maintaining an up to date register of Trust volunteers for the Group Service which is recognised as an ‘Information Asset' under the Data Protection Act
As IAA, ensuring the volunteer register remains up to date and in line with the Trust's responsibilities under the Data Protection Act for ‘Information Assets'
Review of Trust volunteer involvement and providing progress reports to the Trust Board meetings as required
Voluntary Services Support Officer
The Voluntary Services Support Officer is responsible for:
Supporting the maintenance of an up to date register of Trust volunteers for their respective site which is recognised as an ‘Information Asset' under the Data Protection Act;
Undertaking duties of a local site recruitment manager in respect of the recruitment of Trust volunteers;
Ensuring that Trust volunteers receive the required corporate and local induction;
Ensuring that Trust volunteers receive the required mandatory training, particularly in respect of safeguarding compliance;
Provide on-going support and supervision to Trust volunteers;
Service/departmental managers
The service/departmental managers are responsible for:
Identifying suitable volunteering opportunities within their services;
Liaising with the Voluntary Services Coordinator and Manager in the recruitment of suitable volunteer support;
Fully participating in the recruitment process where required;
Providing local induction to the newly recruited volunteer;
Providing local support to the volunteer working in their service area.
Volunteers
Volunteers are responsible for:
Participating fully in the Trust's volunteer recruitment process, including completion of the required pre-employment checks and signing a Volunteer Agreement;

Informing the Trust if they feel they have any condition that could place themselves or patients at risk whilst carrying out their volunteer role with the Trust. In this respect, volunteers are required to complete a Health Questionnaire, and undertake a health screening procedure as defined by the Occupational Health Department;
Undertake a risk assessment on beginning a role/returning to a previous role after a protracted absence due to Covid-19
Complying with Trust Policies and Procedures, particularly in relation to safeguarding requirements;
Raising concerns in accordance with the Trust's Speaking Up-How to Raise a Concern Policy;
Compliance with confidentiality, Information Governance and Data Protection Act requirements;
Attending corporate and local induction training;
Completing the Trust's statutory and mandatory training requirements.
Wearing the volunteer uniform of polo shirt, lanyard and fleece if needed, except if they work in a department which has its own uniform.
Policy statement

The Trust does not employ volunteers to replace paid staff, either temporarily or permanently. Their role is to support the work of staff by performing a range of tasks agreed in advance by the named Line Manager, the Voluntary Services Manager and the volunteer. Neither are they to be employed in times of industrial action to do the work of paid staff. Volunteers enhance rather than substitute the work of paid staff.
The Trust expects that staff at all levels will work positively with volunteers for the benefit of patients.

Volunteers are expected to follow all Trust policies and procedures especially those relating to infection control, patient confidentiality, security, equality and diversity, information governance and health and safety.
Upon placement in a ward/department, the local manager or their named representative will take responsibility for the local induction and on-going supervision, support and welfare of the volunteer.
In accordance with NHS pre-employment check guidelines, all volunteers will complete a Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) check before starting at the Trust
as a volunteer. The DBS process is to be completed using the Trust's on-line DBS service and the outcome recorded on the Volunteer Database

Overall responsibility of the co-ordination of Voluntary Services rests with the relevant Voluntary Services Coordinator who should be notified if a volunteer wishes to transfer to another ward / department or leaves the hospital voluntary service. Any significant changes to the agreement should also be reported to the Voluntary Services Coordinator ensure records are kept up to date. Any voluntary service opportunities should be conveyed to the Voluntary Services Coordinator as soon as they arise.
Principles of good practice

Overall responsibility for volunteers within the Trust rests with the Senior Voluntary Services Manager who will have accountability for carrying out the Trust's policy on recruitment and management of the volunteers, and the authority to ensure it is adhered to by all affected staff. This includes recommending and implementing planned development.

Tasks to be performed by volunteers will be clearly defined in a role description, in order that all concerned with the activities are sure of their respective responsibilities and boundaries. These role profiles will be drawn up by the Senior Voluntary Services Manager in consultation with Heads of Department or their delegates (i.e. Voluntary Services Coordinator and Department managerial lead). Voluntary Services should therefore be informed of any amendments that need to be made to the role in the future.

The Trust accepts that the reimbursing of travel expenses means that volunteering is accessible to all, regardless of income. The Trust does not want to create unnecessary barriers to volunteer involvement. Volunteers will be reimbursed for out of pocket travelling costs – 36 p per mile if travelling by car or at the rate of public transport. Drivers claim 50p per mile. This rate of reimbursement is set by the Trust and will be reviewed periodically. If a volunteer is volunteering more than twice a week and travelling more than 10 miles each way per day it will be for the directorate that they are volunteering in to pay the travel expenses, not the Volunteer Service. Car Parking is provided at the hospital free of charge for all volunteers, whether via a permit or parking receipts reclaimable via expenses.
Volunteers who volunteer for over 4 hours in a single session are entitled to food expense/meal allowances at their local site up to the value of £4.50 and is claimed via a voucher
All volunteers are entitled to claim a hot /cold drink for each session that they volunteer, via a £1.75 voucher.
We are seeking volunteers to commit to a minimum of 4 hours volunteering per week (not necessarily all in one session) and for at least 6 months.
It is now mandatory that volunteers wear the uniform provided, except if they volunteer in a department which already has its own. These volunteers are still

expected to wear the volunteer lanyard. Having a volunteer uniform helps them to be identified and establish a sense of community within the Service. Our uniform is a blue polo shirt or blouse or fleece, and volunteer lanyard.
Rest breaks
Volunteers are required to take a break of 30 minutes in any shift of more than four hours.

Rest breaks must be taken at an agreed time during the period of volunteering and should not be taken either at the start or the end of a period of volunteering time. Volunteers should be able to take this rest break away from their work station.
Recruitment

Once a volunteering opportunity has been identified this will be assessed by the Voluntary Services Manager /Coordinator with the manager of the area to ensure it meets all the recommendations. A role description is confirmed and the plan for recruitment established
Publicity of opportunities and recruitment of volunteers will be the responsibility of the Voluntary Services Manager.

All enquiries should be directed to the Voluntary Services Department and, once received, will be dealt with in a prompt manner. Applications are welcome from anyone aged 16 years or over as per the policy to manage the safety of young workers under the age of 18 years old. Some departments have additional restrictions. There are no upper age limits; however suitability for roles will be individually risk assessed using the Trust's risk assessment framework.
All potential volunteers will be interviewed by either the Voluntary Services Coordinator via telephone, face-to-face or remotely

All prospective volunteers must complete and return an Application Form, with details of two references. Volunteers will also be required to undertake a DBS check (refer to point 3.5) using the Trust's on line DBS service before taking up a volunteer role within the Trust.

If the application form is deemed suitable the Voluntary Services Coordinator will arrange an interview with the potential volunteer. If the volunteer is successful at the interview the Voluntary Services Coordinator will obtain: two references, OH clearance and a DBS check for the volunteer. The result of the clearances will be fed back to the Voluntary Services Coordinator for approval.
The Voluntary Services Coordinator arranges for the volunteer to visit the department.
The Voluntary Services Coordinator will arrange for the volunteer to undertake online mandatory training.
All volunteers must be registered with the Voluntary Services Department, regardless of whether or not they already belong to a voluntary organisation.

Screening and selection. Volunteers are not formally interviewed at their point of enquiring about volunteering. Application forms sent in ‘cold' are assessed for suitability and followed up with an interview. If deemed successful, references are then taken up from two referees. All volunteers must be over the age of 16.

Pre-employment checks. All pre-employment checks are carried out in accordance with the NHS Employment Check Standards, which are mandatory for all applicants for NHS positions in on-going NHS employment, including volunteers. The recruitment procedure largely follows the Trusts policy for Pre and Post Employment Checks.
Document authenticity is an integral part of the verification of identity checks.

All documents are checked thoroughly at the face-to-face interview with the Voluntary Services Coordinator or representative who has suitable counter fraud training. If these checks cannot be completed at the face to face, then as soon as practically possible afterwards if there are any supplementary /clarifying items who will then proceed with the online appropriate DBS once satisfied the documents support the identity of the applicant. No volunteer can be booked on Trust induction or  commence a placement until the results of the Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) check is returned.

Criminal convictions. Should the checks return information that contradicts the details provided by the volunteer and raises concerns, Voluntary Services will refer to the Trust's DBS Policy Statement, which assesses the relevance and the circumstances of offences. This means that a volunteer is invited for an interview with the Voluntary Services Coordinator and a Human Resources manager/representative, if required. The applicant is asked about the circumstances surrounding the offence and a decision will be made about whether to proceed further. All information will be treated in the strictest confidence and may not necessarily prejudice the prospective volunteer's application for voluntary work within the Trust.

Details of two independent referees are provided on the application form and where possible the trust requests that one should be from a professional. Voluntary services cannot accept references from family. These are requested and reviewed by the Voluntary Services Coordinator (VSC) and departmental manager. On successful completion of all stages the volunteer then moves to the commencement of the role.

Final recruitment stage. On successful completion of the pre-employment checks the volunteer will then undertake online mandatory training before commencing their role. The content of mandatory training is detailed in section 6 training requirements.
Once completed evidence is provided to the VSC/CVC and a start date agreed.
On the first day of volunteering the VSC/CVC meets with the volunteer to:
Complete the volunteer agreement, and ensure free car park access is available

Record that the Volunteer has been advised of their obligation to inform the VSL/CVC if there are any changes in their personal circumstances or information that has been provided during the recruitment.
Ensure all contact details, including emergency contacts are correct.
Undertake a risk assessment
Provide information about where to access key staff policies including information governance, health and safety, equality and diversity and infection control policies.
A Trust identification badge is issued to wear at all times when on Trust premises.
Issue the Volunteer Handbook and explain the onsite registration of attendance, the expenses process and the provision of refreshments.
Commencement of volunteering role

On the first day of their placement the volunteer is required to complete with the departmental manager a local Trust induction form, which outlines policy and safety requirements. This is then returned to the VSC/CVC.
The manager is also responsible at this stage
To reiterate the scope of the role and clearly define its boundaries.
Allocate a named member of substantive staff to support and develop the volunteer.
Agree with the volunteer the intervals of supportive 1:1 meetings and role evaluation meetings.
Orientate the volunteer to the department and any other part of the trust that may be relevant to the role.
Agree with VS any training and education arrangements specifically required for the volunteering role. Agree when to evaluate competency.
The manager MUST inform Voluntary Services Department if/when a volunteer
leaves.
Partner organisation assurance (please see MOU App 1)

The Trust also requires assurance that partner volunteer/charitable organisations (e.g. RVS and League of Friends etc.) are also compliant with Trust policy. They are required to evidence that individuals they have recruited to volunteer in the Trust comply with the volunteer checks outlined in this policy before any start date is agreed. The Trust can support employment checks on behalf of the organisation if requested.

All volunteers from other organisations are also required to have completed the agreed Trust mandatory volunteer induction training. They will also be required to wear security badges. These will only be issued by the Trust when the VSC is assured that all the pre-employment checks are completed within policy.
The volunteers attachment agreement and work outlines
If the volunteer is suitable it is the responsibility of the Voluntary Services Coordinator to ensure that:
An agreement is read, completed and signed, with one copy retained by the volunteer, and one copy retained by the Voluntary Services Department via a personal file;
The volunteer is booked on to a Trust Induction day.
The volunteer receives an information pack prior to starting their role at the Trust, which incorporates the following information:
Travelling reimbursement forms and information;
Car parking information;
A basic role description of their volunteer duties
The Voluntary Services Coordinator will assist the volunteer in obtaining the required security / ID card from Trust Security.
The Voluntary Services Coordinator will issue the volunteer in obtaining the correctly sized polo shirt/lanyard which must be worn by the volunteer while on duty
Support and supervision

Voluntary Services and the named Line Manager/contact for the department or ward will support volunteers and assist in any way possible to ensure their integration into the Trust. The staff in the department in which the volunteer is placed are expected to provide sufficient induction support and training for the volunteer to complete their allotted tasks, as per the role description. Risk Assessments for the tasks carried out by volunteers is the responsibility of the ward or department staff where volunteers are placed.
Troubleshooting

If volunteers are dissatisfied with any aspect of their voluntary work, they should first discuss the matter with their named point of contact in the ward or department where they are working. If the issue is not resolved locally or the complaint is with the point of contact, then it can be taken to the voluntary services manager who will decide whether further investigation is appropriate.

Where a volunteer's behaviour causes concern and the problem cannot be resolved informally, it should be referred to the voluntary services manager. The volunteer will have the opportunity to put their case at a specially convened meeting. The volunteer may be accompanied by a person of their choice.

Where the voluntary services manager considers it to be appropriate, further investigation will take place. An informal warning may be issued at this point and it may be that there is a need for further training or extra support to resolve the situation.
If there is insufficient progress after an agreed timeframe, a formal, written warning may be issued, again following an opportunity for the volunteer to put their case.

The final stage is the exclusion of the volunteer. Where a volunteer is accused of committing serious misconduct (this may include theft, acts of violence, harassment, malicious damage, fraud or serious breaches of patient confidentiality) they will be temporarily suspended from their volunteering duties while the matter is investigated. The ward/departmental manager will be advised to complete a serious untoward incident form. If fraud is suspected the local counter fraud specialist will be notified before any other action is taken. Investigation should take no longer than two weeks. The volunteer will have the right to put their case by attending

Support for volunteers will also include regular meetings where appropriate, the issue of a volunteer newsletter to inform them of developments in the Trust, and an annual social event to thank the volunteers.
Regular reviews of volunteer involvement will be held and progress reports will be submitted to the Charitable Funds Committee. A summary on volunteering will be included in the Trusts Annual Report.

Recognition and rewards: Everyone involved in the deployment of volunteers should use all appropriate Informal opportunities to recognise the contribution made by volunteers. In addition there will be an annual reception recognising merit and achievement, to thank all volunteers supporting the hospital, to which the hospital chairman, chief executive, directors, non-executive directors and representatives of the board of governors are invited. This will be done on a site basis to reflect the local nature of volunteering. Where appropriate, nominations come from staff to acknowledge outstanding service or sustained effort in various categories.

Expenses: In recognition of the time freely given by our volunteers the Trust is committed to supporting them and reimbursing reasonable expenses. The Trust reviews the rate and type of expense offered to volunteers on an annual basis. The
current rates are available from the Voluntary Services office.

Volunteers are required to submit their expenses monthly to the VSC. All forms must be fully completed to enable prompt payment into bank accounts incomplete forms will be returned and payment delayed.
It is preferable that expenses are submitted monthly, but should be submitted no later than three months after volunteering.

Where possible all expenses will be paid via BACs transfer and the individual bank details submitted to the VSC. These are held securely with restricted access to the file and the details only shared with finance.

Risk management: Every person has the right to work in a safe environment. Volunteers must comply with the Hospitals' Risk Management policies whilst they are on the premises or engaged in voluntary work on behalf of the hospital. Details

of these policies are available on request. Voluntary drivers must confirm that their own insurance policy covers using their own vehicles as part of their voluntary work. More detailed information is provided in the volunteer's handbook.

IT Access: Some roles may require volunteers to have access to Trust IT systems. Each role will be risk assessed on a case by case basis in consultation with the Digital Service Team and Information Governance Team. The Trust accepts liability for all volunteer activity carried out in line with their role description and in good faith, within the scope of this policy, and properly authorised by hospital staff.

Health and Safety: Volunteers are covered by the Trust's Risk Management and Health & Safety Policy, details of which can be found in their handbook. However, volunteers should be able to meet the demands of the work place without risk to their physical wellbeing. Volunteers must inform the Trust if they feel they have any condition that could place themselves or patients at risk during their activity. Volunteers are required to complete a health questionnaire, and undertake a health screening procedure as defined by the Occupational Health Department.
Acceptance of Gifts:
In line with the Trust Policy, volunteers must not accept any gift, favour or hospitality which may be interpreted as seeking to exert undue influence or obtain preferential treatment.
Rights and responsibilities of volunteers
Raising concerns

If volunteers have views about matters concerning the Trust, they should raise this first with the head of the service they are volunteering in. If this would be difficult for the volunteer, they may instead raise their concerns with the Voluntary Services coordinator.

13.1.1 Volunteers must be aware of the contents of the Trust's policy ‘Speaking up – how to raise a concern'. This policy was formerly the Whistleblowing policy and sets out the process for voicing concerns and can be found on the Trust intranet and website.
Safeguarding
It is the responsibility of every volunteer to safeguard and protect vulnerable adults from abuse. All staff are expected to undertake mandatory training relevant to the role.

13.2.1 The Trust is committed to the Safeguarding of children and young people and has signed up to the Essex Safeguarding Children Policy and Procedures with which the post holder must be familiar as part of undertaking mandatory training
Training requirements

As mentioned earlier, all volunteers returning to their role following a period of inactivity are required to ensure their statutory mandatory training is up to date. Once the volunteer's placement begins, on-going role training remains the responsibility of the line manager to book, and the volunteer to undertake. Mandatory and statutory training remains the responsibility of the VSC to) Failure to do so may result in the volunteer being removed from the department/ward or being asked to leave the service of the Trust.

Voluntary Services have direct responsibility for the initial stat-man and ongoing training of volunteers under its direct supervision, including patient information desks, hospital guides, and care car drivers and ‘Pets as Therapy' (PAT) volunteers. PAT volunteers will also require their own accreditation. This is monitored by the Trust's Statutory and Mandatory Training Group.

Specific training, such as customer care training for frontline volunteers in regular contact with patients and their families must be arranged by the manager. In the case of information desk volunteers and guides, for example, this will be done by the Voluntary Services Coordinator, who is the line manager for this group. The line manager must also arrange a local workplace induction for the volunteer on the first day of placement.

Information Governance: All volunteers are governed by the same rules of confidentiality as paid staff and are required to sign a Volunteer Agreement upon commencement of their voluntary work. All volunteers are instructed that any matters of a confidential nature, including particular information relating to the diagnosis and treatment of patients, must under no circumstances be divulged or passed on to any unauthorised person or persons. Any breach of such confidentiality amounts to gross misconduct warranting dismissal from the voluntary post.
Volunteers will be given the Trust's Information Governance Handbook on appointment as part of their Induction, which they are expected to read.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Charitable Funds Committee which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policies and procedures. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Charitable Funds Committee of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment

The Trust recognises that everyone has a contribution to make to society and a right to equal treatment, and as a result the Trust operates an Equal Opportunities policy in respect of both paid staff and volunteers. A copy is in the policies and procedures file and is available on the Trust website, and it guides all of its dealings with volunteers, particularly in the recruitment, information, policy and practice. (Refer to appendix )

All volunteers will be asked to complete an Equality and Diversity Form once accepted for post. The form asks for details of ethnicity, religion and nationality and is designed to our volunteering workforce is diverse and inclusive. Participation is optional.

Memorandum of Understanding between Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust and External Voluntary/Charitable Organisations (EVCO)
The Trust values the support that external voluntary/charitable organisations (EVCO) provide and acknowledges the beneficial effect for its patients/users and the wider organisation.

It is important that the Trust understands the role that the EVCO will play in the organisation. The Trust acknowledges that relationships with EVCO's must have clear boundaries so that both parties benefit from the involvement and neither is affected detrimentally.

The following sets out the Memorandum of Understanding between Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust and the (name of the EVCO) with regard to volunteering activity undertaken by (name of the EVCO) for or within the Trust.

In the spirit of the local Compact, the Trust will provide the (name of the EVCO) with information regarding planned changes to services that will have an impact on the services provided by the (name of the EVCO).

It is recognised that EVCO's can differ enormously in size and by the infrastructure that they have in place to support the work they do and the valuable contribution they make to the NHS. This document has been written with this in mind, and should be read with consideration to this.

Appendix 5: Volunteer agreement
Volunteers play an important and valued role at MSE Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust. We thank you for offering your gift of time and hope that you enjoy volunteering with us and feel part of our team.

This agreement tells you what you can expect from us, and what we expect from you. We aim to be flexible, so please let us know if you would like to make any changes and we will do our best to accommodate them.
We, MSE FT, will do our best to:
Introduce you to how the organisation works and your role in it, and provide you with any training you need.
Provide you with feedback on your role and provide a main point of contact so that you can tell us if you have any concerns or worries.
Reimburse travel expenses to our current rates (see handbook).
Consult with you and keep you informed of possible changes.
Provide adequate insurance as long as you are following your voluntary role description.
Provide a safe workplace and to provide adequate health and safety mandatory training.
Apply our equal opportunities policy.
Make you feel welcome and to treat you with respect and make you feel part of our team.

At the end of the first 6 weeks of volunteering we will meet with you to evaluate your placement, to ensure it is both effective and appropriate for the volunteer and the Trust. All options will be explored at this meeting.
As a volunteer, you are expected to:
Help the hospital fulfil its services to the community and perform your volunteering role to the best of your ability.
Follow the hospital's procedures and standards, including health and safety and equal opportunities, in relation to staff, volunteers and patients.
Maintain the code of confidentiality at all times and ensure the privacy and dignity of patients, visitors and staff.
Meet time commitments agreed to, and to give reasonable notice of absence or change in circumstances so other arrangements can be made if needed.

You are required to inform the designated supervisor, in writing, of any cautions or convictions you may receive whilst you are volunteering within the Trust. Information provided by you will be treated confidentially. The severity of the offence, impact on your ability to perform your role, possible implications for patient and/or staff safety and your previous history will be some of the factors considered to arrive at an appropriate course of action. You may be required to attend a meeting to discuss the information provided, if deemed appropriate. Failure to inform your Supervisor may result in removal of your services as a Volunteer from the Trust.

For the purpose of the above section, the definition of cautions will be as provided by the DBS, which is currently: “A caution is a formal warning about future conduct given by a senior police officer, usually in a police station, after a person has committed an offence. It is used as an alternative to a charge and possible prosecution.”

A minimum requirement of at least one document from Category 1 is required in order to proceed with the volunteer's application. Applicants ID will be saved in the shared folder to ensure accessibility of documentation. Category 1 Valid passport; Biometric residence permit (UK); Valid UK driving licence (full or provisional) (including Isle of Man/Channel Islands); or Birth certificate (UK and Channel Islands) issued at the time of birth. Correspondence/ID Cards: Bank/Building Society Account Opening Confirmation Letter Letter of Sponsorship from future employment provider (can only be used for applicants residing outside the UK at time of application) EU National ID Card Marriage certificate Adoption certificate Re-issued birth certificate Letter from Head Teacher or College Principal (16 -19 year olds in full time education - exceptional circumstances when all other documents have been exhausted) * Documents issued within the past 12 months: P45 Statement Council Tax Statement Mortgage Statement (UK or EEA) Work Permit/VISA (UK Residence Permit) P60 Statement Financial Statement e.g. pension, endowment, ISA Documents issued within the past 3 months: Bank/Building Society Statement (UK or EEA) Electricity Bill/Statement Gas Bill/Statement# Credit Card Statement (UK or EEA) Water Bill/Statement Telephone Bill/Statement - not mobile telephone Benefit Statement e.g. child allowance, pension Correspondence from A UK Government Agency or Local Authority e.g. Employment Service, Customs & Revenue, Job Centre
